text: <extra_id_0> Interleukin-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression by activated T cells involves an inducible , T-cell - specific factor and an octamer binding protein .

<extra_id_0> Interleukin-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IL-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is exclusively expressed by activated T and natural killer cells , a function that is tightly controlled both in a lineage - specific and in a stimulation - dependent manner .

text: We have investigated the protein binding characteristics and functional importance of the ACT-1-activating region of the <extra_id_0> IL-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .

This region binds an inducible , T-cell - specific factor over its 5 ' end , a site that is necessary for the expression of <extra_id_0> IL-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the absence of other upstream elements .

text: Over its 3 ' end , it binds a factor that is ubiquitously and constitutively expressed .

This factor is <extra_id_0> Oct-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or an immunologically related octamer - binding protein , and it plays a role in coordinating the activity of several regulatory elements .
These characteristics make the ACT - 1 site analogous to the activating ARRE-1 site in the <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .

Furthermore , and despite a lack of sequence homology , the promoters of <extra_id_0> IL-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> share an organizational pattern of regulatory elements that is likely to be important for the T-cell - specific expression of these genes .
